thread.title: Mexico braces for hurricane's 'potentially catastrophic' landfall | News & Features
thread.title_full: Mexico braces for hurricane's 'potentially catastrophic' landfall | News & Features | ArcaMax Publishing

author: arcamax.com
title: Mexico braces for hurricane's 'potentially catastrophic' landfall | News & Features
text:
MEXICO CITY -- The strongest hurricane ever recorded in the Western Hemisphere was poised Friday to make a "potentially catastrophic" landfall on Mexico's southwest coast, forecasters warned.
Hurricane Patricia had sustained wind of 200 mph as it moved toward the Pacific coast state of Jalisco, where it was due to arrive Friday evening, the Miami-based U.S. National Hurricane Center said.
"Preparations to protect life and property should be rushed to completion," the center said in a bulletin, adding that the monster storm "could produce life-threatening flash floods and mudslides."
Hotels in the popular resort town of Puerto Vallarta and other tourist areas boarded up their windows, gathered materials they usually keep on the beach and prepared their convention centers to serve as shelters.
"We have enough supplies for the few guests who do not want to leave," Mily Machuca, a receptionist at the Velas Vallarta hotel, said by telephone. "The rest are leaving the town by land because the airport is closed, or they are heading to shelters."
"The few people who are still in the hotel are right now being asked to go to our convention center, where everything is ready for them: mats, supplies," she said.
Fishing crews were told to remain in harbor, and locals worked to protect their homes and businesses.
Windows were boarded up, and civil protection coordinator Luis Felipe Puente warned people to put away any objects that might "turn into projectiles" and to seek refuge away from glass.
The coast of Jalisco and the neighboring state of Colima is popular with tourists and retired people, including many from the United States and Canada, but it is the low tourist season, and hotels are generally not full.
People in areas that are at risk have been asked to move to higher ground or go to Guadalajara, the region's largest city, away from the danger zone.
"No hurricane of this magnitude has ever made impact on the Mexican Pacific," President Enrique Pena Nieto said on Twitter.
"I gave instructions to the cabinet to reinforce preventive and protective measures for the population in Colima, Jalisco and Nayarit," he wrote, referring to three coastal states that lie in the hurricane's path.
Patricia was a category 5 hurricane, the strongest on the Saffir-Simpson scale of storm intensity, according to the most recent National Hurricane Center bulletin.
"Some fluctuations in intensity are possible today, but Patricia is expected to remain an extremely dangerous category 5 hurricane through landfall," the center said. "After landfall, Patricia is forecast to rapidly weaken over the mountains of Mexico."
